Vittorio De Sica’s role in the Ginar-Sophia scandaletto wa a minor one. The noted
actor-producer also figured in a minor way in one of two announced retirements that have
attracted much attention recently.
One involved Beniamino Gigli, the Italian operatic tenor, whom many critics call the
greatest since Caruso, Gigli is now 65 years old and in the 41st year of his singing career.
He made his retirement announcement in London during a strenuous concert tour that will also
take him to the United States and Canada. It was a strange kind of retirement announcement.
The interviewer said Gigli spoke with a voice full of emotion. He described his de¬
cision as a "tremendous" and "sorrowful" one that required great will power. But then it
turned out that Gigli intends to retire only from the operatic stage and concert tours. He

The other prominent retirement announcement seemed much more final. It concerned the
retirement of the former Italian bicycle racing champion, Qino Bartali. Bartali now is 40
years old and had been racing 23 years. During that time, he won 153 victories in national
or international competition and in the course of them he bicycled the equivalent of 16 trips
around the world.
Tlie Italian sports writers pulled all stops in reporting Gino’s retirement, for he was
a national sports hero in a way that Americans, who have never gotten very excited about
cycling, would find it hard to understand.
